Notes: Schools in Perth, Peel and Southwest of WA will be closed from Monday 1 February as part of the 5-day lockdown restrictions for these areas. The latest health advice of Sunday 31 January is that parts of WA - Perth, Peel and the Southwest - go into a 5-day lockdown from 6pm Sunday 31 January to 6pm Friday 5 February. All schools in these areas will be closed as an extension of the school holidays and no lessons or supervision will be provided.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210208171737/https://www.education.wa.edu.au/current-schooling-arrangements  ***Updated to include correctly archived link

The VIC govt COVID19  website states that "new restrictions apply from 11:59pm, Wednesday 3 February 2021"..."In line with advice from the Victorian Chief Health Officer, all high-school students and school-based staff must carry a face mask at all times and wear a face mask in indoor settings such as schools, early childhood education centres and places of study, unless an exception applies."  The VIC govt COVID19 website also outline physical distancing requirements for schools, which include that adults at school (staff and visitors) must maintain a 1.5m distance and also density limit of 1 person per 2m squared.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208012821if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/face-masks-study-and-school https://web.archive.org/web/20210208013113if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/physical-distancing-health-and-hygiene  ***Updated to indicte this policy on actual start date of Feb 3

15/02/2021: Changed from T1 to T3.  Monday the 8th February is the first school day after the announcement and implementation of this policy change.       WA Premier Mark McGowan press release dated 4th Feb 2021 states, in part, " Current lockdown ends, pending no further local cases, as planned at 6pm tomorrow [5th Feb 2021]"..."Under the post-lockdown transition measures, Perth and Peel schools will start from Monday, February 8, with the mandatory mask rule applying to all school staff and secondary students. Masks are not required for primary school students."  While schools are open.  However, mandatory mask wearing is public health precautions that result in significant differences as compared to usual, non-Covid-19 operations. 15th Feb 2021 changed from T3 to T1 as the 15th February is the first school day impacted by this policy change.     12th Feb 2021: In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide,  lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021.  Lock-down regulations for the Education and childcare sector are: Early learning centres, childcare, family day care: Open. School: Schools closed but open for vulnerable children and the children of essential workers. Higher education and training: Closed, remote learning only.  As schools and Higher education and training are closed (with the exception of vulnerable children or children of essential workers) changed code to 3T.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85

In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide,  lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021.  Lock-down regulations for the Education and childcare sector are: Early learning centres, childcare, family day care: Open. School: Schools closed but open for vulnerable children and the children of essential workers. Higher education and training: Closed, remote learning only.  As schools and Higher education and training are closed (with the exception of vulnerable children or children of essential workers) changed code to 3T. 15th February is the first school day impacted by this policy change.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85

A 17 February 2021 media release from the Victorian Government published on the Victorian State Government Health and Human Service website announced that "Restrictions under Victoria’s new circuit-breaker actions will end tonight. From 11:59pm 17 February 2021 Victoria returns to COVIDSafe Summer restrictions – with some revised conditions.... There will no longer be four reasons to leave home and the five-kilometre restriction will no longer apply. Schools, restaurants and retails can reopen and both public and private office workers can return up to 50 per cent on site."  Schools across VIC have reopened.  In VIC Students age 12 yrs and older must where a mask while indoors at school and it is strongly recommended outside. Staff are required to practice 1.5m distancing with other adults where ever possible.  Density limits of one person per two square metres apply to staff areas such as staff lunchrooms and areas accessed by the public, such as reception areas.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220060525/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20(Victoria)%20(No%2015)%2017%20February%202021%20(signed).pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219220907/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-17-february-2021    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222013328if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/physical-distancing-health-and-hygiene    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222013320/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/face-masks-study-and-school

People in the city of two million - along with people living in the nearby Peel and South West regions - must stay at home, except for essential work, healthcare, food shopping or exercise, said Western Australia state Premier Mark McGowan.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131225608/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-55877150

***Recoded to reflect the required continued closing of casinos and nightclubs in Perth and Peel regions for the post-lockdown 14 day incubation period (1G to 2T)     WA:   WA Premier Mark McGowan press release dated 4th Feb 2021 states, in part, " Current lockdown ends, pending no further local cases, as planned at 6pm tomorrow [5th Feb 2021]"..."The post lockdown transitional measures for the Perth and Peel regions, include: ... All business and venues can re-open, except for the casino and nightclubs;  4 square metre capacity rule and 150-person capacity at hospitality, entertainment, fitness venues and events including weddings, funerals (excluding staff);".   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208010107/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/02/Post-lockdown-plan-to-come-into-effect-6pm-Friday-February-5.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207114449/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/transition-out-of-lockdown-6pm-friday-5-february     VIC:   The VIC Govt. COVID19 websites states that "if you can’t work from home you can go to work. Workers who must attend onsite due to the nature of the work may continue to do so and there is no limit on the number of people who can attend. From Monday 18 January 2021, up to 50 per cent of office workers who are not in the public service have been able to return to on-site work as well as up to 25 per cent of public service workers. Offices with fewer than 40 staff can have 20 staff on-site subject to density quotients." This is up to date at 8th Feb 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208014511/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/work-and-study    QLD:   The QLD GOVT. COVID -19 website states that from “1am AEST 22 January 2021, the Greater Brisbane region is subject to the same restrictions as the rest of the state.” … “All restricted businesses can open, in line with the COVID Safe Framework. All restricted businesses may now have one person per 2 square metres on their premises, other than a hospitality business that does not comply with the requirement to collect contact details electronically. Venues can operate with up to 100 per cent seated capacity if patrons are in ticketed, allocated seating. Dance floors are also allowed indoors and outdoors, and you can stand up and have a drink at bar.”  All businesses can open.  However, there are requirements for some businesses to collect customer contact details, some density requirements.  Some venues and events are required to use a COVID checklist or develop a COVID Safe Event Plan.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208020314/https://www.health.qld.gov.au/system-governance/legislation/cho-public-health-directions-under-expanded-public-health-act-powers/business-activity-undertaking-direction   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208020752/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/easing-greater-brisbane-restrictions     NSW:   Current as of 8th Feb 2021, The NSW Government COVID19 website outlines current restrictions on businesses.  Restrictions vary by type of business and include: mandatory staff mask wearing, customer density rules (one person per 2 or 4 square meters), and maximum numbers of people allowed in specific venues of events.  There are no current mandatory work from home restrictions in NSW.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208020752/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/easing-greater-brisbane-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114055257/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/covid-safe     ACT:   The Australian Capital Territory Public Health (Restricted Activities –Gatherings, Business or Undertakings) Emergency Direction 2020 (No16), in effect since 11:59pm Mon 16 December 2020 and still current does not require the closure of any business.  However, it does outline restrictions including use of the ACT Government tracing App; total number of allowable customers; customer density requirements; and maximum allowable percentage of venue capacity used.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208030940/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/business-and-work  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208030914/https://www.legislation.act.gov.au/ni/2020-801/     TAS:   According to the Tasmania Government’s COVID-19 website, las updated 5th February 2021, “All businesses and workplaces are permitted to operate, but must implement measures to meet the minimum COVID-19 safety standards and record this in a COVID-19 Safety plan.”  Measures include mandatory contact tracing, maximum allowable numbers within venues/spaces, and maximum allowable percentage of venue capacity used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208031511/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/business-and-employees/business-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208031755/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/gatherings-density-and-physical-distancing     SA:  The current South Australia Emergency Management (Public Activities No 18) (COVID-19) Direction 2021 does not require the closing of any business.  However, it does stipulate a range of restrictions on business operations.  Restrictions include: maximum person densities, that food and beverage must be consumed while seated at hospitality venues, appropriate personal protective equipment be worn by staff providing personal care services; maximum allowable percentage of venue capacity used.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208032027/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/documents/emergency-directions-covid-19/Emergency-Management-Public-Activities-No-18-Direction-2021.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208032042/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/business-and-work/business-restrictions-and-closures    NT:   The Northern Territory COVID-19 Directions (No. 56) 2020: Safety Measures for Places, Businesses, Activities, Services and Premises does not require the closing of any business.  However, it does require that businesses provide customers with hand sanitiser, collection contract information from customers, ensure physical distancing of 1.5M otherwise keepi9ng contact to less than 15 minutes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208043605/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0012/951879/cho-directions-no56-safety-measures-places-businesses-activities-services-premises.pdf

12th Feb 2021: In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide,  lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021.  Lock-down regulations include that : If you can work from home, you must work from home.  Essential workers and workplaces may remain open and are defined in information provided at the PDF link.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85

WA: In a further easing of restrictions Western Australian Premier Mark McGowan announced that "The Perth and Peel restrictions will end as planned at 12.01am, Sunday, February 14.This means the whole of Western Australia will return to the pre-lockdown conditions, as experienced prior to 6pm on Sunday, January 31....Western Australians should continue to practise physical distancing where possible, maintain good personal hygiene at all times and get tested when unwell. It is vital that all Western Australians ensure they are registering their contact details, at businesses and venues where contact registers are mandatory, to assist contact tracing if it is required. As was the case before the lockdown, public or private events involving more than 500 patrons that require local government authority approval will need an approved COVID Event Plan as part of that process." All businesses are allowed to reopen though some COVIDsafe measures remain in place.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210222020726/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do  http://web.archive.org/web/20210222021353/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/02/Return-to-pre-lockdown-life-from-12-01am-Sunday-February-14.aspx      VIC: In an easy of restrictions, a 17 February 2021 media release from the Victorian Government published on the Victorian State Government Health and Human Service website announced that "Restrictions under Victoria’s new circuit-breaker actions will end tonight. From 11:59pm 17 February 2021 Victoria returns to COVIDSafe Summer restrictions – with some revised conditions.... There will no longer be four reasons to leave home and the five-kilometre restriction will no longer apply. Schools, restaurants and retails can reopen and both public and private office workers can return up to 50 per cent on site."  All workplaces are open with restrictions including recordkeeping, maximum people, percentage capacity restrictions, mask carrying/wearing, record keeping requirements,  square meter capacity rules, and 1.5m distance rules.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210222023521if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-work  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220060525/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20(Victoria)%20(No%2015)%2017%20February%202021%20(signed).pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219220907/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-17-february-2021    NSW:  The most recent updates to the Public Health (COVID-19 Restrictions on  Gathering and Movement) Order (No 7) 2020 made on 11th February 2021.  The direction prohibits Nightclubs operating within Greater Sydney, Central Coast, and Wollongong.  No other work places are prohibited from operating.  However, there remain capacity restriction (square meter rules and percentage capacity) and record keeping    https://web.archive.org/web/20210222043855/https://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Restrictions%20on%20Gathering%20and%20Movement%29%20Order%20%28No%207%29%202020_210212.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209073400/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/greater-sydney    Therefore reverted coding to T2 from T3.

12th Feb 2021: In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide,  lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021.  Lock-down regulations include that Public gatherings are Not permitted (exception is two people for exercise, or members of your household).   An exception has been made for "professional athletes are defined as essential workers, venues hosting professional sporting competitions can open, with essential staff attending to ensure the safe running of the event. No spectators." On face value, this appears to have been designed to allow the Australian Open tennis competition to continue (with no spectators).   Funerals (indoor and outdoor) may go ahead with no more than 10 people (and those necessary to conduct the funeral).  Weddings are not permitted unless end of life or other exceptional reasons. Involves only 5 persons  (including the two persons being married, celebrant, two witnesses)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85

VIC: In an easy of restrictions, a 17 February 2021 media release from the Victorian Government published on the Victorian State Government Health and Human Service website announced that "Restrictions under Victoria’s new circuit-breaker actions will end tonight. From 11:59pm 17 February 2021 Victoria returns to COVIDSafe Summer restrictions – with some revised conditions.....  The Victorian Government COVID-19 website states that: "Up to 20 people can meet outdoors in a public place. There is no limit on the number of households those people come from."... "Large indoor venues, such as the NGV and Princess Theatre, can open for up to 50 per cent capacity of the total venue with a maximum of 300 patrons in each space. Density caps apply to non-seated areas."..."Indoor seated entertainment venues also have limits of 50 per cent of seating capacity and up to 300 patrons per space."..."Outdoor entertainment venues have limits of 75 per cent capacity and up to 1000 patrons. Density caps apply to non-seated areas."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220060525/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20(Victoria)%20(No%2015)%2017%20February%202021%20(signed).pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219220907/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-17-february-2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222044743/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live

Parts of Western Australia went into a five-day lockdown Sunday, after a hotel security guard tested positive for coronavirus.  The Perth metropolitan area and the Peel and South West regions of the Australian state are now under "full lockdown," Premier Mark McGowan announced Sunday, with residents only able to leave their homes for essential shopping, medical needs, exercise, and for jobs that cannot be done at home or remotely.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131225608/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-55877150 https://web.archive.org/web/20210207114449/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/transition-out-of-lockdown-6pm-friday-5-february

There is no limit on the number of households those people come from."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208044750if_/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/social-gatherings#how-many-visitors-can-i-have-to-my-house

WA:   In an easing of restrictions to the Perth and the Peel Region of WA; Premier Mark McGowan press release dated 4th Feb 2021 states, in part, " Current lockdown ends, pending no further local cases, as planned at 6pm tomorrow [5th Feb 2021]".  The WA COVID19 website states that restrictions for the Perth and Peel region of WA currently includes that private outdoor and indoor gatherings are limited to 20 people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208010107/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/02/Post-lockdown-plan-to-come-into-effect-6pm-Friday-February-5.aspx  https://web.archive.org/web/20210206092332/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do       VIC:   As stated thon the VIC Government COVID-19 website, as of 11:59pm 3 February 2021 state-wide restrictions include that “the limit on the number of people gathering in a household is reduced from 30 to 15, meaning the household members plus 15 visitors (excluding children under 12 months of age).”  This restriction remains in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208044750/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/social-gatherings     WA and VIC are currently the jurisdictions with the most stringent restrictions on private gatherings in Australia.

12th Feb 2021: In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide,  lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021.  Lock-down regulations include that Private gatherings are not permitted (i.e. no visitors allowed to a household). However, intimate partner visits are allowed.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85

VIC: In an easy of restrictions, a 17 February 2021 media release from the Victorian Government published on the Victorian State Government Health and Human Service website announced that "Restrictions under Victoria’s new circuit-breaker actions will end tonight. From 11:59pm 17 February 2021 Victoria returns to COVIDSafe Summer restrictions – with some revised conditions.... There will no longer be four reasons to leave home and the five-kilometre restriction will no longer apply." The VIC Govt COVID-19 website informs citizens that "You can have up to five visitors to your home per day, meaning the household members plus five visitors (children under 12 months of age do not count towards the five-person cap). "..."You can meet in groups of up to 20 people in a public outdoor space from any number of households. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220060525/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20(Victoria)%20(No%2015)%2017%20February%202021%20(signed).pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219220907/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-17-february-2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222044743/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live

Advice for people arriving from interstate  All residents and travellers from anywhere in Australia wishing to enter Victoria from 6pm 11 January 2021 must apply for a permit.    Areas will be designated green, orange or red zones by the CHO based on public health advice. Restrictions will apply for different zones.    Interstate services  Passengers will be able to resume travelling from Albury Station towards Melbourne on train services from Monday 1 February.    V/line coach services which travel through NSW have resumed operating for the entire journey across the NSW border.     /web/20210201221850/https://www.ptv.vic.gov.au/more/coronavirus-covid-19/

People in the city of two million - along with people living in the nearby Peel and South West regions - must stay at home, except for essential work, healthcare, food shopping or exercise, said Western Australia state Premier Mark McGowan.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131225608/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-australia-55877150

In an easing of restrictions for the Perth and Peel region, WA Premier Mark McGowan press release dated 4th Feb 2021 states, in part, " Current lockdown ends, pending no further local cases, as planned at 6pm tomorrow [5th Feb 2021.   While restrictions on gatherings remain in place (variously total number of people, square meter rules, and need to wear a mask) all people in the Perth and Peel region of WA are able to leave their homes for non-essential reasons.  So long as residents follow these restrictions it does not appear that they are being discouraged from leaving their homes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208010107/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/02/Post-lockdown-plan-to-come-into-effect-6pm-Friday-February-5.aspx   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207114449/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/transition-out-of-lockdown-6pm-friday-5-february

12th Feb 2021: In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide,  lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021.  Lock-down regulations include that residents must "Stay at home unless:  • Shopping for necessary goods and services (one person per household, once per day, a support person can accompany  if required)  • Caregiving or compassionate reasons  • Essential work or permitted education  • Exercise (can leave for two hours of exercise)  • Other specified reasons (specific exemptions apply)"    There is also an Intrastate travel: travel limit of 5km from place of primary residence.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85

VIC: In an easy of restrictions, a 17 February 2021 media release from the Victorian Government published on the Victorian State Government Health and Human Service website announced that "Restrictions under Victoria’s new circuit-breaker actions will end tonight. From 11:59pm 17 February 2021 Victoria returns to COVIDSafe Summer restrictions – with some revised conditions.... There will no longer be four reasons to leave home and the five-kilometre restriction will no longer apply." While restrictions re mask wearing and gathering remain, The VIC Govt COVID-19 is no longer restricting citizens from leaving their homes.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210220060525/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/202102/Stay%20Safe%20Directions%20(Victoria)%20(No%2015)%2017%20February%202021%20(signed).pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219220907/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-update-victoria-17-february-2021  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222044743/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/how-we-live

Advice for people arriving from interstate  All residents and travellers from anywhere in Australia wishing to enter Victoria from 6pm 11 January 2021 must apply for a permit.    Areas will be designated green, orange or red zones by the CHO based on public health advice. Restrictions will apply for different zones.   /web/20210201221850/https://www.ptv.vic.gov.au/more/coronavirus-covid-19/

Each Australian State and Territory has different boarder travel restrictions in place.  Changes implemented on the 4th Feb 2021 are:   WA:   WA Government announcement published 29 January 2021 – stated that from 12.01am, Friday 5th February Victoria would move from the ‘low risk’ to ‘very low risk’ category.  “Under the ‘very low risk’ category, safe travel is permitted into WA, subject to the following updated conditions: completion of a G2G PASS prior to travel, stipulating: they do not have any COVID-19 symptoms, which jurisdictions the traveller has been in over the previous 14 days, undergoing a health screening and temperature test if arriving at Perth Airport, being prepared to take a COVID-19 test at the airport COVID clinic, if deemed necessary by a health clinician, undergoing a health screening if arriving by land.” The announcement further stated that “New South Wales remains at ‘low risk’ category, which means travel is permitted subject to strict conditions including 14 days of self-quarantine and COVID-19 testing”.    However, at 7:51pm AEST 4th February 2021, Premier Mark McGowan reversed the decision to move Victoria from a ‘low risk’ to a ‘very low risk’ category.  At the 4th Feb 2021, WA considers NSW and VIC to be ‘low risk’.  WA considers all other Australian states and territories to be ‘very low risk’.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208054724/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/queensland-and-victoria-transition-very-low-risk-category   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208060723if_/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=264413555047497&set=a.263657845123068     ACT:   On the 4th February 2021, Victoria imposed new state-wide restrictions starting today after a hotel quarantine worker at the Grand Hyatt Hotel tested positive to COVID-19.  The ACT government stipulated that “If you are currently in the ACT, and you have been in a Tier 1 Victorian exposure site or identified as a close contact, you must immediately enter quarantine and get tested for COVID-19. You must complete an online declaration form within 24 hours of the Public Health Direction coming into effect today. You must remain in quarantine for 14 days from the date on which you attended the exposure site.” Further “If you are planning to enter the ACT, and you have been in a Tier 1 Victorian exposure site or identified as a close contact, you are required by DHHS to quarantine in Victoria. You must not travel to the ACT without an exemption from ACT Health as well as from Victorian authorities. Your exemptions must be granted prior to travel.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208063357/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/news-articles/new-travel-restriction-for-covid-19-affected-areas-of-victoria   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208063501/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/case-locations-and-outbreaks-covid-19     NT:   As documented on the NT Government COVID-19 website: The Melbourne (VIC) LGAs of Brighton, Clayton South, Heatherton, Keysborough, Melbourne, Moorabbin Airport, Noble Park, Springvale, West Melbourne, and Wheelers Hill – were declared hot spots at 3:30pm (NT time) 4th Feb 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208072331/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19

Each Australian State and Territory has different boarder travel restrictions in place.  Outlined below are changes implemented on 5th February 2021.     ACT:   In an easing of travel restrictions, the ACT lifted all restriction to travellers from the WA Perth and Peel region from 6pm AEST 5th February 2021.  The restriction had been in place since 2pm AEDT 1st Feb 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208062659/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/news-articles/travel-restrictions-in-wa-lifted    NT:  As documented on the NT Government COVID-19 website: Perth and the Peel region WA were declared hot spots between 7:30pm (NT time) 31st Jan 2021 and 7:30pm (NT time) 5th Feb 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208072331/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19     QLD:   As documented on the QLD Government COVID-19 website:From 1am AEST Saturday 6 February 2021 the 12 LGAs that make up the South West region of Western Australia are removed as COVID-19 hotspots.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208070602/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/hotspots-covid-19     NSW:   As documented on the NSW Government COVID-19 website “From the 5th February 2021, Victoria is declared an affected area. Arrivals by air or rail must complete a declaration form.  If you are not a NSW resident and you have been in a place of high concern you must not enter NSW. If you are a returning NSW resident and you have been in a place of high concern at the time specified in a COVID-19 concerns notice, you must self-isolate for 14 days, and follow the Interstate Traveller Guidelines.“  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208063914/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/border-restrictions   In an easing of restrictions, as documented on the NSW Government COVID-19 website “The Public Health (COVID-19 Western Australia) Order has been repealed. From 9pm on Friday 5 February: There is no requirement to provide a declaration when entering NSW from Western Australia, and there is no obligation for anyone from WA to follow a stay at home direction. Visit the Government of Western Australia – locations visited by confirmed cases for case locations in Western Australia. Follow the advice on testing and self-isolation rules if you have visited any of these locations.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208064831/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/interstate-hotspots   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208065142/https://www.legislation.nsw.gov.au/file/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Western%20Australia%29%20Order%202021.pdf     VIC:   In an easing of restrictions, as documented on the VIC Government COVID-19 website: “Victoria’s Chief Health Officer has declared the Perth metropolitan area, the Peel region and the South West region of Western Australia will move from a red zone to an orange zone under Victoria’s ‘traffic light’ travel permit system at 9pm Victorian time today, Friday 5 February.”  Further “Following continued low community transmission and exposure risk, from 6:00pm on 29 January 2021 the last red zone in New South Wales, the Local Government Area (LGA) of Cumberland, has transitioned to an orange zone. All remaining orange zones have transitioned to green. Anyone with a valid permit will be able to enter Victoria from New South Wales.” This was current as of 8th Feb 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208065455/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covid-19-daily-update  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208065849/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/victorian-travel-permit-system     SA:  As documented on the SA Police Border Travel website:   2.	“In effect from 3:26 pm 5 February 2021 [and still current 08th Feb 2012]:    The regions of Peel, Perth and South West are now considered a restricted zone [this is an easing of previous restriction].  Travellers arriving from Peel, Perth and South West, must self-quarantine at a suitable place and submit to COVID-19 testing on day 1, 5 and 12. They can be released from self-quarantine upon written advice of a negative COVD-19 test result.  All travellers who are required to undertake a COVID-19 test on days 1, 5 and 12 must wear a mask any time they come into contact with the public until they have received their first negative COVID-19 test result.  Travellers who are already in South Australia and arrived from those Peel, Perth and South West are now released from self-quarantine upon written advice of a negative test result, with the exception of persons who had been in the Sheraton Four Points Hotel who must complete their supervised quarantine.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208073826/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/emergency-declarations/cross-border-travel

Upon written confirmation of a negative COVID-19 result, person is released from the self-quarantine requirement, but must complete the testing regime.”    2.	“In effect from 3:26 pm 5 February 2021 [and still current 08th Feb 2012]:    The regions of Peel, Perth and South West are now considered a restricted zone [this is an easing of previous restriction].  Travellers arriving from Peel, Perth and South West, must self-quarantine at a suitable place and submit to COVID-19 testing on day 1, 5 and 12. They can be released from self-quarantine upon written advice of a negative COVD-19 test result.  All travellers who are required to undertake a COVID-19 test on days 1, 5 and 12 must wear a mask any time they come into contact with the public until they have received their first negative COVID-19 test result.  Travellers who are already in South Australia and arrived from those Peel, Perth and South West are now released from self-quarantine upon written advice of a negative test result, with the exception of persons who had been in the Sheraton Four Points Hotel who must complete their supervised quarantine.”    3.	Effective 12:01 am on 31 January 2021 [and still current 08th Feb 2012]   [This is an easing of previous restriction] A non-essential traveller who is travelling from Greater Sydney Region, Central Coast LGA, or Wollongong LGA, will be permitted to enter South Australia if they self-quarantine at a suitable location and submit to COVID-19 testing within 24 hours of arrival, on day 5, and again on day 12. This also applies to South Australian residents who have travelled from the Greater Sydney Region, Central Coast LGA, Wollongong LGA. Once the person receive a negative test result (in writing), there will no longer be a requirement to remain in quarantine. Testing on day 5 and day 12 will still be mandatory.   No restrictions apply to travellers coming from New South Wales if they have not been in the prohibited locations (Greater Sydney Region, Central Coast LGA, or Wollongong LGA).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208073826/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/emergency-declarations/cross-border-travel     TAS  As documented on the TAS Government COVID-19 website: Some specific premises at defined times and dates have been identified as ‘High Risk’.  These specific premises are in Melbourne VIC and Sydney/Wollongong NSW.  Travellers who have spent time in a high-risk premise or location in the 14 days before arriving in Tasmania are not permitted to enter Tasmania, unless approved as an Essential Traveller.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208074113/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208074301/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert

Border restrictions apply to anyone who have been in a hotspot in the previous 14 days or since the start date identified for the hotspot (whichever is shorter). For these Western Australia hotspots, the identified start date is 1am AEST 25 January 2021. This is the date is when the risk of COVID-19 transmission started.”  This is current as of 11th February 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208070602/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/hotspots-covid-19      NT:  As documented on the NT Government COVID-19 website: The Melbourne (VIC) LGAs of Maidston, Sunshine, and Taylors Lakes were declared 3:30pm (NT time) 8th Feb 2021 and remain current.  The Melbourne LGA of Sunbury was declared on 9am 10th Feb 2021 and remains’ current.  The Holiday Inn Melbourne Airport, 10-14 Centre Rd, Melbourne Airport, Victoria 3045 was declared 4:00pm 10th Feb 2021 and remains current.  Anyone arriving into the Northern Territory from or through a declared hotspot in the last 14 days must undertake 14 days mandatory supervised quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211061915/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19     WA: As of 11th Feb 2021, WA considers NSW and VIC to be ‘low risk’.  WA considers all other Australian states and territories to be ‘very low risk’.  14 day quarantine applies to travellers from 'low risk' areas.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211054102/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-interstate-border     As of 8th February 2021, tourists and travellers (including from within WA) are not allowed to enter some remote Aboriginal communities.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208063753/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-remote-aboriginal-communities-travel   As of 11th Feb 2021, documented on the WA government’s COVID-19 website, “Only essential travel permitted in and out of the Perth and Peel regions to other parts of WA.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211054538/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/department-of-the-premier-and-cabinet/covid-19-coronavirus-what-you-can-and-cant-do#Travel     SA:   In a tightening of restrictions, the SA Government COVID-19 website documents that “For travel on or after 12.01 am 11 February 2021; for persons who have been in Greater Melbourne on or after 4 February 2021, will be prohibited from entering South Australia unless they are an Essential Traveller or an exempt person (returning SA resident, genuine relocation, fleeing Domestic Violence – who will be required to self-quarantine at a suitable place for 14 days upon arrival and submit to COVID-19 testing on day 1, 5 and 12 pursuant to their restrictions).”     In a continuation of restrictions, “From 12:01 am 31 January 2021, travel is permitted from Greater Sydney, Wollongong and the Central Coast to South Australia. Upon arrival, travellers must immediately self-quarantine and must remain in that place until a negative COVID-19 test result is received. They must submit a COVID-19 test within 24 hours after their arrival, on the 5th day after their arrival and on the 12th day after their arrival in South Australia.” This remains current as at 11th Feb 2021.     In a continuation of restrictions “The regions of Peel, Perth and South West are now considered a restricted zone. Travellers arriving from Peel, Perth and South West, must self-quarantine at a suitable place and submit to COVID-19 testing on day 1, 5 and 12. They can be released from self-quarantine upon written advice of a negative COVD-19 test result. All travellers arriving from a restricted location who are required to undertake a COVID-19 test on days 1, 5 and 12 must wear a mask any time they come into contact with the public until they have received their first negative COVID-19 test result.”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210211020613/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/restrictions-and-responsibilities/travel-restrictions     TAS  In a continuation of restrictions and as documented on the TAS Government COVID-19 website: Some specific premises at defined times and dates have been identified as ‘High Risk’.  These specific premises are in Melbourne VIC and Sydney/Wollongong NSW.  Travellers who have spent time in a high-risk premise or location in the 14 days before arriving in Tasmania are not permitted to enter Tasmania, unless approved as an Essential Traveller.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210131102813/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/medium-risk-areas   Locations continue to be updated.  A list of up to date locations, as at the 11th Feb 2021 can be viewed at this link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211062826/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert

Each Australian State and Territory has different boarder travel restrictions in place.  Below are changes implement on 12th Feb 2021.    VIC: 12th Feb 2021: In a tightening of restrictions the Premier of Victoria announced a 5 day, Victoria Wide, lock-down from 11:59pm Friday 12th February 2021 until 11:59pm on Wednesday, 17 February 2021. Consequently, there is an Intrastate travel limit of 5km from place of primary residence.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053031/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/sites/default/files/2021-02/210212%20-%20Table%20of%20restrictions.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212053116/https://www.premier.vic.gov.au/statement-premier-85    ACT: The ACT COVID-website was updated in 12th Feb 2021 to include an alert “Travel restrictions for Victoria will be in effect from 11.59pm Friday 12 February. More information coming soon.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201110716/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/community/travel     WA: One the 12th Feb 2021, In a media statement, WA Premier Mark McGowan, announced that Victoria be reclassified as 'medium risk' (previously ‘low risk’) for a short period, until the situation is controlled. Beginning tonight, from 6pm, the 'medium risk' category will come into force until at least 12.01am, Tuesday, February 16, pending updated health advice.  The 72 hour hard border with Victoria means only exempt travellers are permitted.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212060056/https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2021/02/Return-to-pre-lockdown-life-from-12-01am-Sunday-February-14.aspx   NT:   The Northern Territory Government COVID-19 website was updated on 12th Feb to include 31 more Melbourne LGAs as declared hotspots from 10:45am 12th Feb 2021 – current.  Details of these LGAs can be found at the link.  Mandatory quarantine is required for people entering the NT who have visited a declared hotspot.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211061915/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19

WA: A press release on the Western Australian Government COVID-19 website states that the "NSW will move from ‘low risk’ to ‘very low risk’ at 12.01am, on Tuesday, 16 February, pending no further outbreaks.  Under the ‘very low risk’ category, safe travel is permitted into WA subject to the following updated conditions:  completion of a G2G Pass declaration, stipulating they do not have any COVID-19 symptoms and which jurisdictions the traveller has been in over the previous 14 days;  all Perth Airport arrivals to undergo a health screening and temperature test;  travellers to be prepared to take a COVID-19 test at the airport COVID clinic, if deemed necessary by a health clinician (voluntary asymptomatic testing also available); and  land arrivals to be met at the border checkpoint, for a health screening and to have their G2G Pass declaration checked.  "  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222073452/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/announcements/return-pre-lockdown-life-1201am-sunday-14-february

Each Australian State and Territory has different boarder travel restrictions in place.  Below are the current restrictions as of 26th Feb 2021.  Note has been made of Australian State/Territories that have restricted travel from Auckland New Zealand.  However, code provided is based on restrictions on movement internal to Australia only.     VIC:   Victoria has no current restrictions on movement within the state nor across borders with other Australian jurisdictions.  Victoria has declared that “From 11.59pm Wednesday 24 February all flights arriving from Auckland [New Zealand] into Victoria will be regarded as ‘red zone’ arrivals and anyone arriving will be required to enter mandatory hotel quarantine for 14 days.??   Those who arrived in Melbourne from Auckland yesterday, Tuesday 23 February, are asked to get a COVID-19 test immediately and quarantine until they receive a negative test result.??”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226090601/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/travel-updates   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226090552/https://www.dhhs.vic.gov.au/coronavirus-covid-19-daily-update    ACT:   ACT has no current restrictions on movement within the state nor across borders with other Australian jurisdictions.  However, from 25 February 2021, travellers who have arrived into Australia and have been in Auckland in the 14 days prior to their arrival (excluding transits via Auckland Airport), must not travel to the ACT.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226093352/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/community/travel/overseas     NSW:  NSW has no current restrictions on movement within the state nor across borders with other Australian jurisdictions. The NSW Govt has declared Auckland New New Zealand a hot spot.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226091152/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/border-restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226091206/https://www.health.nsw.gov.au/Infectious/covid-19/Documents/interstate-concerns-notice.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226091415/https://www.nsw.gov.au/covid-19/what-you-can-and-cant-do-under-rules/quarantine    WA:   WA continues to declare VIC an area of ‘low risk’.  Travellers from ‘low risk’ areas “If you have suitable premises, enter self-quarantine for 14 days. If not, you will be directed to enter a Government-approved quarantine facility at your own expense for 14 days. You must present for a COVID-19 test on Day 11 if still in WA.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226091951/https://www.wa.gov.au/organisation/covid-communications/covid-19-coronavirus-controlled-interstate-border   Under the WA Government’s Remote Aboriginal Communities Directions, the only people who can enter a remote Aboriginal community are residents of those communities and those who are:  providing essential services and supplies  going to work or school there  entering for family or cultural reasons  delivering a community program or activity  entering in an emergency.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226091842/https://www.wa.gov.au/government/publications/remote-aboriginal-communities-directions-no-3  https://web.archive.org/web/20201002224654/https://www.wa.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-08/Remote%20Aboriginal%20Communities%20Directions%20%28No.%203%29.pdf    NT:   The NT has no active Australian declared hotspots.  Therefore the NT has no current restrictions on movement within the state nor across borders with other Australian jurisdictions.  The NT has declared specific locations within Auckland to be hotspots.  “In accordance with direction 35 and with reference to direction 35A of the Directions for Territory Border Restrictions (No.49) (consolidated version PDF (188.5 KB), the CHO requires any person who has arrived in the Northern Territory from New Zealand to be tested for COVID 19 if:   They arrived between 19 February 2021 and 5:59pm on 25 February 2021; and  They were in any of the locations of interest declared by the NZ Ministry of Health listed below on or about the relevant times and dates listed below.  A person who is required to be tested must travel directly to a suitable place of quarantine and remain in that place, except to submit to testing for COVID-19 (or in an emergency). Once tested, the person must remain isolated in the suitable place of quarantine until notified of the results of the test.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226092118/https://coronavirus.nt.gov.au/travel/quarantine/hotspots-covid-19     SA:   In an easing of restrictions the SA govt covid-19 website states that   “In effect from 12:01 am 26 February 2021:  Travel from Victoria and Greater Melbourne is permitted.    Travellers who arrived from Greater Melbourne and are subject to quarantine – if they have been to a high risk site are to remain segregated and isolated and contact SA Health regarding self-quarantine and COVID-19 testing requirements.  Travellers who arrived from Greater Melbourne and were not in a high risk site, can leave self-quarantine but must complete their day 1, 5 and 12 COVID-19 testing. However, if a person needs to attend a high risk setting (health, disability, aged care or correctional facility), they need to let the facility know they have been in High Community Transmission Zone in the past 14 days and will need to wear Personal Protective Equipment.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226092624/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/restrictions-and-responsibilities/travel-restrictions     QLD:  The QLD Govt website states that: “From 1am AEST Saturday 13 February 2021 specific Victorian LGAs are declared as COVID-19 hotspots. Border restrictions apply to anyone who have been in a hotspot in the previous 14 days or since the start date identified for the hotspot (whichever is shorter). For these Victorian hotspots, the identified start date is 7 February 2021. This date is when the risk of COVID-19 transmission started.”  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226093034/https://www.qld.gov.au/health/conditions/health-alerts/coronavirus-covid-19/current-status/hotspots-covid-19     TAS:   TAS has no current restrictions on movement within the state nor across borders with other Australian jurisdictions.  Tasmania has declared the Auckland region, New Zealand to be high risk.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226034224/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226093308/https://coronavirus.tas.gov.au/travellers-and-visitors/coming-to-tasmania/travel-alert

According to the Australian Government Department of Home Affairs website, "Australia has strict border measures in place to protect the health of the Australian community. Very limited flights are currently available to and from Australia and you may not be able to travel at this time... You are automatically exempt from the travel restrictions and can enter Australia (without obtaining an individual exemption) if you are:  an Australian citizen  a permanent resident of Australia  an immediate family member of an Australian citizen or permanent resident*  a New Zealand citizen usually resident in Australia and their immediate family members  a person who has been in New Zealand for 14 days or more immediately prior to arrival by air in Australia  a diplomat accredited to Australia, including their immediate family members (each member of the family unit must hold a valid subclass 995 visa)  a person transiting Australia for 72 hours or less  airline crew, maritime crew including marine pilots  a person recruited under the Government approved Seasonal Worker Program or Pacific Labour Scheme  a person who holds a Business Innovation and Investment (subclass 188) visa."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208231635/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/travel-restrictions

The Australian Government Department of Home Affairs website states that "From Thursday, 25 February 2021, any traveller from New Zealand who has been in Auckland (except for transit through the airport from a connecting flight) for any period over the previous 14-days, is not eligible to travel on a quarantine-free (green zone) flight.  Any travellers from New Zealand who have not been in Auckland for any period over the previous 14-days are still eligible to travel on a quarantine-free (green zone) flight."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223135041/https://covid19.homeaffairs.gov.au/new-zealand-safe-travel-zone    The Australian department of health website further states that "On 24 February 2021, the Australian Chief Medical Officer advised:As a result of the recent community transmission of a variant of concern in Auckland, New Zealand, Auckland will be designated a Commonwealth hotspot.  No person who has been in Auckland in the last 14 days will be permitted to board a green flight into Australia.  Auckland airport, for the purposes of travel only, is exempt.  Normal green flight arrangements will continue for travellers who have not been in Auckland in the last 14 days.    These arrangements will commence at 11.59 pm AEDT Wednesday, 24 February 2021 and operate until 11.59 pm 6 March 2021.  "   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226085455/https://www.health.gov.au/news/health-alerts/novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov-health-alert/coronavirus-covid-19-restrictions/coronavirus-covid-19-advice-for-international-travellers

No change in policy - The current JobKeeper wage subsidies have been extended through 28 March 2021 with payment reductions to facilitate a gradual transition to a recovery. The Commonwealth government also instituted a new JobTrainer skills package (A$2 billion). Pandemic Leave Disaster Payment has been arranged with the State and Territory governments to provide a lump sum payment to help workers during their 14-day self-isolation period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107164553/https://www.ato.gov.au/General/JobKeeper-Payment/JobKeeper-extension-announcement/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210107165916/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

11th Feb 2021:   According to the Australian Government Treasury website, Jobkeeper continues to be paid to eligible employers who must must pass the full payment onto their eligible employees.  To be currently eligible to receive job keeper: Businesses and not-for-profits will need to demonstrate that they have met the relevant decline in turnover test in the December 2020 quarter to remain eligible for the March 2021 quarter.   https://treasury.gov.au/sites/default/files/2020-10/Fact_sheet-JobKeeper_Payment_extension_0.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211070818/https://treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/jobkeeper/extension     According to the Australian Government Treasury website, Coronavirus Supplement : The Australian Government has a range of income support payments for eligible residents.  In response to COVID-19 the Australian Government introduced an additional and automatic Coronavirus Supplement for those already receiving JobSeeker Payment, Youth Allowance, Parenting Payment (Partnered or Single), Austudy, ABSTUDY (Living Allowance), Farm Household Allowance, Special Benefit or Department of Veteran's Affairs Education Scheme, or if an eligible New Enterprise Incentive Scheme participant. From 1 January 2021, the Coronavirus Supplement will be $150 per fortnight until 31 March 2021.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211073457/https://treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/households/increased-income-support     According to the Australian Government Treasury website, Extra Payments for Pensioners: "Two separate $750 payments have made to households and two more payments of $250 each will be made recognising the ongoing impact of the Coronavirus pandemic." The last payment is scheduled for  26 February 2021.  Further details at the link:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211074135/https://treasury.gov.au/coronavirus/households/extra-payments-pensioners       According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Full-time adult average weekly earnings  was $1,713.90 for the May 2020 reference period.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210211073835/https://www.abs.gov.au/statistics/labour/earnings-and-work-hours/average-weekly-earnings-australia/latest-release

A media release on the Prime Minister of Australia, Scott Morrison's, website published 23rd Feb 2021 stated that teh govt is "permanently increasing the income-free earnings to $150 per fortnight for JobSeeker Payment and Youth Allowance (other) from 1 April 2021;"  The Australian Government Services Australia website states that the "The Coronavirus Supplement is available at a rate of $150 per fortnight until 31 March 2021." "The temporary Coronavirus Supplement ends 31 March 2021.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210225044939/https://www.pm.gov.au/media/morrison-government-commits-record-9b-social-security-safety-net    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226075154/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/services/centrelink/coronavirus-supplement/how-much-you-can-get    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226075355/https://www.servicesaustralia.gov.au/individuals/news/how-changes-coronavirus-covid-19-support-may-impact-y

On 24 September 2020, the Government announced changes to Australia’s insolvency framework to better serve Australian small businesses, their creditors and their employees. The changes, which commenced on 1 January 2021, introduce new insolvency processes suitable for small businesses by reducing the complexity, time and costs required.  The changes will enable more Australian small businesses to quickly restructure in order to survive the economic impact of COVID-19. Where restructure is not possible, businesses can wind up faster, enabling greater returns for creditors and employees.  These reforms are the most significant changes to the Australian insolvency framework in almost 30 years. They form part of the Government’s JobMaker plan to ensure Australia emerges from the pandemic with a stronger, more resilient and more competitive economy. The need to give businesses and their creditors certainty is crucial to kick-starting confidence and activity as the economy transitions to the recovery phase.  /web/20210201223455/https://business.gov.au/risk-management/emergency-management/coronavirus-information-and-support-for-business/temporary-relief-for-financially-distressed-businesses

Currently, as at the 12th Feb 2021, each state and territory has somewhat different household level debt and contact relief COVID-19 Reponses in place.  However, the only type of COVID-19 related household relief that appears to apply across all jurisdictions is in relation to residential rental payments and/or contracts.     ACT:   According to the ACT government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021: The annual increase will not be applied to 2020-2021 annual rates bills, The ACT Revenue Office will implement a new process for rates deferrals for owner occupiers experiencing hardship because of COVID-19. No interest will apply to the deferred amount, The Government is providing land tax and rates rebates to landlords of residential properties who reduce rents by at least 25 per cent for tenants impacted by COVID-19, The ACT Government is offering stamp duty concessions in the ACT for some home buyers planning to live in their new property, All 2020-21 vehicle registration, parking and public transport fee increases at the current levels., Households already receiving the Utilities Concession will receive an additional $200 rebate through their electricity bill, The government will freeze the Utilities Network Facilities Tax (UNFT) at the current  level.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131103022/https://www.covid19.act.gov.au/business-and-work/economic-survival-package/families-and-households    NSW:  According to the ACT government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021: measures to restrict when landlords can evict tenants due to rental arrears as a result of COVID-19;   https://web.archive.org/web/20210108104616/https://www.fairtrading.nsw.gov.au/resource-library/publications/coronavirus-covid-19/property/moratorium   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212033050/https://www.nsw.gov.au/life-events/living-nsw/renters-financially-affected-by-coronavirus    QLD:   According to the QLD government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021:   There remain some temporary regulatory measures to 30 April 2021 means Queensland remains ready to respond to COVID-19 risks as the transition back to normal residential tenancy arrangements continues.  These are: provisions allowing tenants experiencing domestic and family violence to end their tenancies quickly; protections for tenants against being listed in a tenancy database for rent arrears caused by COVID-19 impacts; limits on reletting costs for eligible tenants who end their fixed term tenancies early; short term tenancy statement extensions for moveable dwellings; entry restrictions and requirements to support COVID-19 social distancing measures; relaxed repair and maintenance obligations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125024414/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/the-hub/covid-19-tenancy-update     VIC:   According to The Victorian Government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021, COVID-19 changes to renting laws (implemented 29 March 2020 and still in effect) mean that tenants in financial hardship cannot be given a notice to vacate; landlords must try to negotiated a temporary rent reduction agreement where it is needed by tenants because of the impacts of COVID-19. Tenants can apply for a rent relief grant of up to $3,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212051024/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/renting-laws-and-support-during-coronavirus-covid-19-pandemic     NT:  According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021 “On 24 April 2020, the Northern Territory Parliament passed the Tenancies Legislation Amendment Act 2020. This provides the framework for the Territory’s response to tenancy issues arising as a result of the COVID-19 emergency.” These modifications: Extending notice timeframes for certain pre termination actions under the Act; establish New processes for termination of a tenancy; and provide for modified entry and inspection processes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200930194941/https://nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/818308/s28.pdf     WA: According to The Western Australian Government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021” “In response to COVID-19, the Western Australian Government implemented a moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases, under the Residential Tenancies (COVID-19 Response) Act 2020. The extended emergency period ends on 28 March 2021, which means that all the existing laws will stay in place until this date, after which the ordinary tenancy laws will apply again.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201105910/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response   SA:  According to SA Government COVID-19 website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021 “State Parliament has endorsed a number of initiatives aimed at helping landlords and tenants whose incomes have been affected by COVID-19.” This includes “Ensuring tenants cannot be evicted by landlords due to an inability to paid rent because of COVID-19 employment loss”.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210212043922/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/school-and-community/housing-and-in-the-community     TA:   According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021.  “Some of the changes to the Residential Tenancy Act 1997 including changes to rental evictions, rental increases, and general repairs and maintenance expired on 31 January 2021.” However, The Tasmanian Government is providing rent relief for residential households who rent homes in the private market and who are experiencing housing stress because of the impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19).  The Support Funds are available until 31 March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212044429/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/rental-housing

These are: provisions allowing tenants experiencing domestic and family violence to end their tenancies quickly; protections for tenants against being listed in a tenancy database for rent arrears caused by COVID-19 impacts; limits on reletting costs for eligible tenants who end their fixed term tenancies early; short term tenancy statement extensions for moveable dwellings; entry restrictions and requirements to support COVID-19 social distancing measures; relaxed repair and maintenance obligations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212040959/https://www.covid19.qld.gov.au/the-hub/covid-19-tenancy-update    VIC:   According to The Victorian Government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021, COVID-19 changes to renting laws (implemented 29 March 2020 and still in effect) mean that tenants in financial hardship cannot be given a notice to vacate; landlords must try to negotiated a temporary rent reduction agreement where it is needed by tenants because of the impacts of COVID-19. Tenants can apply for a rent relief grant of up to $3,000.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226073918/https://www.coronavirus.vic.gov.au/renting-laws-and-support-during-coronavirus-covid-19-pandemic    NT:  According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021 “On 24 April 2020, the Northern Territory Parliament passed the Tenancies Legislation Amendment Act 2020. This provides the framework for the Territory’s response to tenancy issues arising as a result of the COVID-19 emergency.” These modifications: Extending notice timeframes for certain pre termination actions under the Act; establish New processes for termination of a tenancy; and provide for modified entry and inspection processes.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226074036/https://consumeraffairs.nt.gov.au/rental-changes-due-to-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226074039/https://nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/818308/s28.pdf    WA: According to The Western Australian Government website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021” “In response to COVID-19, the Western Australian Government implemented a moratorium on some evictions and all rent increases, under the Residential Tenancies (COVID-19 Response) Act 2020. The extended emergency period ends on 28 March 2021, which means that all the existing laws will stay in place until this date, after which the ordinary tenancy laws will apply again.”   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226074155/https://www.commerce.wa.gov.au/consumer-protection/residential-tenancies-covid-19-response  SA:  According to SA Government COVID-19 website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021 “State Parliament has endorsed a number of initiatives aimed at helping landlords and tenants whose incomes have been affected by COVID-19.” This includes “Ensuring tenants cannot be evicted by landlords due to an inability to paid rent because of COVID-19 employment loss”.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210226074235/https://www.covid-19.sa.gov.au/school-and-community/housing-and-in-the-community    TA:   According to The Northern Territory Consumer Affairs website, and current as at 12th Feb 2021.  “Some of the changes to the Residential Tenancy Act 1997 including changes to rental evictions, rental increases, and general repairs and maintenance expired on 31 January 2021.” However, The Tasmanian Government is providing rent relief for residential households who rent homes in the private market and who are experiencing housing stress because of the impact of the coronavirus (COVID-19).  The Support Funds are available until 31 March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226074304/https://www.coronavirus.tas.gov.au/families-community/rental-housing

In addition to the preexisting campaign, a Media release by Greg Hunt Minister for Health and Aged Care published 27 January 2021 announced that "a public information campaign to encourage Australians to get a COVID-19 vaccine begins today. The campaign will keep Australians fully informed and up to date about the safety and effectiveness of COVID-19 vaccines as they become available, including when, how and where to get the jab."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210204082400/https://www.health.gov.au/ministers/the-hon-greg-hunt-mp/media/australias-covid-19-vaccine-information-campaign-begins
