January 18, 2021: "To date, the country is still under community quarantine measures, wherein schools are still closed, and people who are at high-risk are now allowed to go out, unless for essential travels."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210127211646/https://www.news-medical.net/news/20210118/Understanding-the-Philippines-relative-success-with-COVID-19.aspx

On 10 February, the Commission of Higher Education and the Department of Health approved guidelines for the gradual reopening of colleges and universities for limited face-to-face classes in areas under general community quarantine (GCQ) and modified general community quarantine (MGCQ).    Higher education institutions with medical and allied health degree programs will be prioritized, including medicine, nursing, medical technology/medical laboratory science, physical therapy, midwifery, and public health.     Other institutions wanting to hold limited physical classes must submit an application. Education authorities will then visit the campus to inspect its compliance with requirements for face-to-face classes.    “The subjects or courses under these priority programs shall be allowed for face-to-face delivering are delimited to specialized laboratory courses or hospital-based clinical clerkship/internship/practicum, including clinical rotations for post-graduate medical interns”    Areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) through March 5, 2021:  Pasay City (Barangays 28, 29, 32,40, 57, 58, 66, 68, 71, 76, 81, 95, 98, 100, 107, 109, 118, 122, 132, 135, 136,143, 155, 156, 159, 162, 175, 177, 178, 183, 190, 192, 201 and one establishment);    Areas under General Community Quarantine (GCQ) through February 28, 2021:  Luzon – National Capital Region, Cordillera Administrative Region: Abra, Apayao, Benguet, Baguio City, Ifugao, Kalinga, and Mountain Province, Province of Batangas; Visayas – Tacloban City; Mindanao – Iligan City, Davao del Norte, Lanao del Sur.    All other areas, including cities of Santiago and Ormoc, are under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301020932/https://doh.gov.ph/sites/default/files/health-update/jmc2021-001.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information

No change to previous policy. General community quarantine (GCQ) has been extended to February 28 in regions with high COVID-19 activity. See DTI and DOLE INTERIM GUIDELINES ON WORKPLACE PREVENTION AND CONTROL OF COVID-19 at:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210116031735/https://www.dole.gov.ph/news/dti-and-dole-interim-guidelines-on-workplace-prevention-and-control-of-covid-19/

In areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine, the following businesses are allowed to operate at full capacity:  Public and private hospitals; health, emergency and frontline services, including those provided by dialysis centers, chemotherapy centers; manufacturers of medicines, medical supplies, devices and equipment, including suppliers of input, packaging, and distribution; industries involved in agriculture, forestry, and fishery and their workers, including farmers, Agrarian Reform Beneficiaries (ARBs), fisherfolk, agri-fishery stores, and such other components of the food value chain; delivery and courier services, whether in-house or outsourced, transporting food, medicine, or other essential goods, including clothing, accessories, hardware, housewares, school and office supplies, as well as pet food and other veterinary products.    In areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine, the following business are allowed to operate at a maximum of 50% capacity:  Private establishments and their employees involved in the provision of essential goods and services, and activities in the value chain related to food, medicine and vitamins production, medical supplies, devices and equipment, and other essential products. Such establishments shall include, but shall not be limited to, public markets, supermarkets, grocery stores, convenience stores, laundry shops, food preparation establishments insofar as take-out and delivery services, water-refilling stations; media establishments and their total permanent staff complement, inclusive of reporters and other field employees; workers accredited by the Department of Transportation (DOTr) to work on utility relocation works.    Areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) through March 5, 2021:  Pasay City (Barangays 28, 29, 32,40, 57, 58, 66, 68, 71, 76, 81, 95, 98, 100, 107, 109, 118, 122, 132, 135, 136,143, 155, 156, 159, 162, 175, 177, 178, 183, 190, 192, 201 and one establishment);    Areas under General Community Quarantine (GCQ) through February 28, 2021:  Luzon – National Capital Region, Cordillera Administrative Region: Abra, Apayao, Benguet, Baguio City, Ifugao, Kalinga, and Mountain Province, Province of Batangas; Visayas – Tacloban City; Mindanao – Iligan City, Davao del Norte, Lanao del Sur.    All other areas, including cities of Santiago and Ormoc, are under Modified General Community quarantine (MGCQ).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301040743/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/economic/establishments    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301035212/https://www.covid19.gov.ph/static/resources/estab.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information

"To curtail the coronavirus outbreak, the government has implemented non-pharmaceutical interventions, including school closures, community quarantines, and postponement of large-scale public events."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210127211646/https://www.news-medical.net/news/20210118/Understanding-the-Philippines-relative-success-with-COVID-19.aspx    Mass gatherings were prohibited in Metro Manila since March 2020, and was lifted in select areas in June 2020. These restrictions have not been fully lifted everywhere.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210221202811/https://www.who.int/philippines/internal-publications-detail/covid-19-in-the-philippines-situation-report-70

In areas under General Community Quarantine, Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine, or Enhanced Community Quarantine, mass gatherings such as but not limited to, movie screenings, concerts, sporting events, and other entertainment activities, community assemblies, and non-essential work gatherings are prohibited.    In areas under Modified General Community Quarantine, mass gatherings such as but not limited to, movie screenings, concerts, sporting events, and other entertainment activities, religious services, and work conferences are allowed provided that participants are limited to 50% of the seating or venue capacity.    Areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) through March 5, 2021:  Pasay City (Barangays 28, 29, 32,40, 57, 58, 66, 68, 71, 76, 81, 95, 98, 100, 107, 109, 118, 122, 132, 135, 136,143, 155, 156, 159, 162, 175, 177, 178, 183, 190, 192, 201 and one establishment);    Areas under General Community Quarantine (GCQ) through February 28, 2021:  Luzon – National Capital Region, Cordillera Administrative Region: Abra, Apayao, Benguet, Baguio City, Ifugao, Kalinga, and Mountain Province, Province of Batangas; Visayas – Tacloban City; Mindanao – Iligan City, Davao del Norte, Lanao del Sur.    All other areas, including cities of Santiago and Ormoc, are under Modified General Community quarantine (MGCQ).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The IATF Omnibus Guidelines on the Implementation of Community Quarantine in the Philippines does not explicitly describe restrictions on private gatherings.     However, the restrictions on leaving the house would suggest that private gatherings would not be possible in areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine:  Strict home quarantine shall be observed in all households, and the movement of all residents shall be limited to accessing essential goods and services, and for work in permitted offices or establishments as well as specified activities.      Areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) through March 5, 2021:  Pasay City (Barangays 28, 29, 32,40, 57, 58, 66, 68, 71, 76, 81, 95, 98, 100, 107, 109, 118, 122, 132, 135, 136,143, 155, 156, 159, 162, 175, 177, 178, 183, 190, 192, 201 and one establishment);    Areas under General Community Quarantine (GCQ) through February 28, 2021:  Luzon – National Capital Region, Cordillera Administrative Region: Abra, Apayao, Benguet, Baguio City, Ifugao, Kalinga, and Mountain Province, Province of Batangas; Visayas – Tacloban City; Mindanao – Iligan City, Davao del Norte, Lanao del Sur.    All other areas, including cities of Santiago and Ormoc, are under Modified General Community Quarantine (MGCQ).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf

In areas under Modified Enhanced Community Quarantine and Enhanced Community Quarantine, public transportation is suspended. This notwithstanding, commissioned shuttle services for employees of permitted offices or establishments, as well as point-to-point transport services provided by the government shall be allowed to operate, giving priority to healthcare workers.     In areas under General Community Quarantine and Modified General Community Quarantine, the road, rail, maritime, and aviation sectors of public transportation are allowed to operate at such capacity and following the protocols as provided for by the DOTr.     Areas under Enhanced Community Quarantine (ECQ) through March 5, 2021:  Pasay City (Barangays 28, 29, 32,40, 57, 58, 66, 68, 71, 76, 81, 95, 98, 100, 107, 109, 118, 122, 132, 135, 136,143, 155, 156, 159, 162, 175, 177, 178, 183, 190, 192, 201 and one establishment). All other areas, including cities of Santiago and Ormoc, are under Modified General Community quarantine (MGCQ).      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf
Curfews for various regions continue to be in effect.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208024826/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Due to the rising COVID-19 cases, the barangay has once again strictly enforced quarantine protocol, allowing only money remittance centers, pharmacies and gasoline stations to operate every Sunday starting February 14, 2021."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221204943/https://www.philstar.com/the-freeman/cebu-news/2021/02/16/2078142/sunday-stay-home-policy-lahug-starts

In all areas, strict home quarantine shall be observed in all households, and the movement of all residents shall still be limited to accessing essential goods and services, and for work in permitted offices or establishments or such specified activities.    Any person below 15 years old, those who are over 65 years old, those with immunodeficiency, comorbidity, or other health risks, and pregnant women, including any person who resides with the aforementioned, shall be required to remain in their residences at all times, except when indispensable under the circumstances for obtaining essential goods and services, or for work in industries and offices or such other activities permitted in this section.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf

No change to previous policy.  "Checkpoints are in place and domestic air travel remains limited. LGUs my request information about your purpose of travel. In general, leisure travel is not permitted at this time."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208024826/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"The timing for each curfew is set by the Local Governmental Unit (LGU) and varies by region...  Checkpoints are in place and domestic air travel remains limited. LGUs my request information about your purpose of travel. In general, leisure travel is not permitted at this time."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221205117/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The movement of the following authorized persons outside their residences (APOR)  within and across areas placed under any form of community quarantine shall be  permitted:  Health and emergency frontline services personnel  Government officials and government frontline personnel  Duly-authorized humanitarian assistance actors (HAAs)  Persons traveling for medical or humanitarian reasons  Persons going to the airport for travel abroad  Anyone crossing zones for work or business permitted in the zone of destination, and going back home.    The following persons shall also be considered as APOR:  Returning or repatriated OFWs and other Overseas Filipinos (OFs) returning to their places of residence  Other persons transported through the efforts of the national government upon observance of the necessary quarantine protocols and with the concurrence of the receiving LGUs.    The Philippine National Police shall be authorized to promulgate and regularly update the list of APORs.    Authorized shuttle services shall be allowed to travel within and across areas placed under any form of community quarantine, with priority given to persons rendering health and emergency frontline services.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf

As of February 1, foreign nationals are permitted to enter the Philippines, provided accomodations have been pre-booked for at least 7 nights in an accredited quaratine facility. Upon entry, passengers are required to undergo a COVID-19 RT-PCR test at the?airport.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208024826/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Philippines is currently limiting the entry of U.S citizens and foreign nationals into the country. Only U.S. citizens with a Philippine visa can travel directly to the Philippines provided that they contact the nearest Philippine Embassy or Consulate before attempting travel. In addition, starting December 7, 2020, Filipino citizens’ foreign spouses and children, and  former Filipino citizens (including their spouses and children) will be allowed visa-free entry into the country. Pre-booked quarantine facility and pre-booked COVID-19 testing at a laboratory operating at the airport are required for these visitors."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221205329/https://intentionaltravelers.com/philippines-travel-restrictions/

The following individuals are allowed to enter the Philippines:  9(E) visa holders – diplomats accredited to the Philippines including foreign embassies and Foreign Government and International Organization Officials  Foreign airline crew  9(C) visa holders – Foreign Seafarer Visa  9(D) visa holders – Treaty Trader Visa (US, Japan, and Germany)  Section13 Series of Commonwealth Act No. 613, as amended (13 quota, 13A, 13B, 13C, 13D, 13E, 13G visas)  RA7919 visa holders (The Social Integration Act of 1995) – granted to qualified foreign nationals who entered the country prior to 30 June 1992  EO324 visa holders – Legal residence granted under EO324 for qualified foreign nationals who entered the Philippines before 1 January 1984  Native Born (NB) visa holders – Foreign children born to foreigners with permanent resident status in the Philippines  Temporary Resident Visa (TRV) holders (based on MO ADD-01-038 / ADD-02-015 [Indians])  MCL-07-021 Permanent Resident visa holders – Chinese nationals married to Filipino citizens    The entry of all persons allowed to enter the Philippines under relevant IATF resolutions shall be subject to the following conditions:  Pre-booked accommodation for at least 7 nights in an accredited quarantine hotel/facility  COVID-19 testing at the quarantine hotel/facility on the 6th day from date of arrival      https://web.archive.org/web/20210211040850/https://www.philippineairlines.com/en/ph/home/covid-19/ArrivingInThePH/EligiblePaxForTravelToPH    https://web.archive.org/web/20210226082834/https://dfa.gov.ph    https://web.archive.org/web/20210224220511/http://www.immigration.gov.ph

Public health information continues to be disseminated by the central government of the Philippines.

The COVID-19 Dashboard (covid19.gov.ph) provides statistics for cases, recovered patients, and deaths. Additionally, news, press briefings, and vaccine information is featured. Currently 170 laboratories using RT-PCR are accredited for COVID-19 testing, as well as 50 laboratories using GeneXpert."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221202811/https://www.who.int/philippines/internal-publications-detail/covid-19-in-the-philippines-situation-report-70

Real-Time Reverse Transcription-Polymerase Chain Reaction (rRT-PCR) and antigen (rapid) testing are readily available throughout the country, including at  Philippine Department of Health (DOH) accredited testing centers.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210302050733/https://hfsrb.doh.gov.ph/1729-2/

On 2 February, Speaker Lord Allan Velasco filed House Resolution No. 1536, which proposes a unified national contact tracing protocol that includes the designation of a government agency or body as the centralized repository of information to facilitate a faster health emergency response system.    Velasco stressed the need to strengthen the government’s contact tracing efforts using the most effective and safest system to further boost its response to the Covid-19 pandemic.    He cited that the Philippines is only able to identify at least 7 contacts per coronavirus-infected person when the ideal contact tracing ratio should be 1:37 for urban areas, and 1:30 for rural communities.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302051017/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1130162

"The Philippine government mandated all persons to wear full-coverage face shield together with face masks?while in public places." Fines or arrests for non-appliance continue to be enforced.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208024826/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"The Philippine government mandated all persons to wear full-coverage face shield together with face masks?while in public places. Local governments continue to implement additional requirements to slow the virus’ spread.  ...  Consequences, such as fines or arrests, for non-compliance with Philippine rules regarding social distancing, movement restrictions, and mask/face shield mandates vary according to the LGU."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221205117/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All persons are mandated to wear full-coverage face shields together with face masks, earloop masks, indigenous, reusable, or do-it-yourself masks, or other facial protective equipment which can effectively lessen the transmission of COVID-19, whenever they go out of their residences, pursuant to existing guidelines issued by the national government subject to fair and humane penalties or punishments that may be imposed by LGUs or implemented by law enforcement agencies, respectively.       https://web.archive.org/web/20210301032920/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301051743/https://app.adpc.net/sites/default/files/public/publications/attachments/IATF-EID%20210211%20%E2%80%93%20Omnibus%20Guidelines%20on%20the%20Implementation%20of%20Community%20Quarantine%20in%20the%20Philippines%20with%20Amendments%20as%20of%20February%2011%2C%202021.pdf

On February 7, priority list for vaccinations are announced. A (health workers, uniformed personnel), C (senior citizens), and B (indigent residents): Pfizer-BioNtech vaccine    "At least 537,820 Dabawenyos will receive the first shots when the coronavirus disease 2019 (Covid-19) vaccines are rolled out here, the City Health Office (CHO) said Thursday. The priority groups include 16,677 health workers, 77,189 senior citizens, 5,258 uniformed personnel, and 432,549 indigent residents."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221211457/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1131032    "The Philippine Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has granted authorization for emergency use of Pfizer BioNTech’s and AstraZeneca’s COVID-19 vaccines in the Philippines."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210221205117/https://ph.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On 25 February, Health Secretary Francisco Duque said that Sinovac Biotech’s COVID-19 vaccine is safe and effective, citing assurances from the medical community.    The country expects to receive the first delivery of 600,000 doses of Sinovac COVID-19 vaccines donated by the Chinese government.    It is also awaiting the delivery of 3.5 million doses of vaccines manufactured by AstraZeneca and Pfizer, through the COVAX Facility, a global alliance that seeks to help poor countries vaccinate their populations.    Galvez, who is also the chief implementer of the National Task Force Against COVID-19, reported that for the first quarter, the Philippines will receive a total of 5.1 million vaccine doses.    In the second quarter, a total of 24.1 million doses is expected to be delivered to the Philippines, which will come from COVAX and government procurements.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061146/https://pia.gov.ph/press-releases/releases/1067871

On 28 February, the 600,000 doses of Sinovac-made vaccines finally arrived in Manila on Sunday as part of China's commitment to supporting the Philippines' vaccination rollout.    The Chinese military plane carrying the donated vials called CoronaVac landed at the Villamor Airbase in Pasay City past 4 p.m. and was welcomed by several Cabinet members.    President Rodrigo Duterte also witnessed the historic event and inspected the crates containing the vials, the first-ever to arrive in the Philippines, during its ceremonial turnover to the Philippine government.    In his speech, Duterte thanked the Chinese government for the vaccine donation, confident that more batches of vaccines will be available at the earliest possible opportunity.    “I convey my sincere gratitude to the Chinese people and the government of China for this gesture of friendship and solidarity – the hallmark of Philippines-China partnership,” he said.    Duterte also reiterated his statement that Covid-19 vaccines should be treated as a global public good and made available to all, rich and poor alike    “No nation – no people - should be left to suffer the ravages of this pandemic for whatever reason," he said.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210302061604/https://www.pna.gov.ph/articles/1132107

The measures in the new normal  are as follows:    Clean your hands often. Wash with soap and water or use an alcohol based sanitizer;  Keep a physical distance of at least 1.5 meters between yourself and others;  Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth;  Greet others with a smile, a nod or a simple hello-no handshakes, no fist bumps and no high fives;  Cough and sneeze in your bent elbow and not your hands;  Limit social gathering and time spent in crowded places;  Wear a face mask or face covering in all public places to protect yourself and others; and  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://covid19.info.gov.pg/index.php/2021/02/01/manning-calls-on-schools-to-observe-covid-19-protocols-as-2021-academic-year-begins/

Children are going 'back-to-school' as the new academic year starts, and are instead asked to take precautions to prevent the spread of Covid-19 under the "Niupela Pasin" campaign. Papua New Guinea continues to implement social-distancing measures nationwide due to ongoing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) activity. Authorities continue to ban gatherings of more than 50 people. Religious congregations, sporting events, and markets are exempt from the restrictions, but these establishments must ensure adequate social distancing and that patrons observe safe hygiene practices. Tighter measures, including a curfew and travel restrictions, are ongoing in West New Britain Province through at least 6:36 AM until 2/4/2021,  http://web.archive.org/web/20210111174819/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/424826/papua-new-guinea-covid-19-restrictions-continue-nationwide-as-of-jan-4-update-24

No mention of the cessation of the West New Britain's curfew/lockdown, which was supposed to last at least until the 4th of February (per the data notes by Rancy Chadha on 3rd Jan, 20th Jan, and 2nd Feb). Instead, a Facebook post by PNG's National Department of Health on 6th February (https://archive.vn/90Ytu) suggests that the special measures implemented in West New Britain province are still ongoing.    As such, the special measures (Measure 13) pertaining to WNB still apply. Per Measure 13 of the National Pandemic Act 2020, enacted on 31st December 2020 for as long as the WNB curfew/lockdown persists,  "6. All forms of public gatherings are prohibited, except for the main listed provincial market/s, supermarkets, fuel stations, sea ports, airports, hotels, banks, pharmacies, restaurants, heath care providers and shops licensed to trade which may remain open."    See the Measure, archived on Dropbox, at https://www.dropbox.com/s/jlfnnmkeri4nkrl/PNGMeasure13-WNB-20201230.pdf

As per the US Embassy in PNG,     "Movement Restrictions:    1) Is a curfew in place? A national curfew not currently in place. However, as of January 1, 2021, the National Pandemic Controller imposed a 10pm-5am daily curfew in West New Britain Province in response to a rise in COVID-19 cases. All non-emergency travel is restricted during the curfew hours.  2) Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? As of January 1, 2021, the National Pandemic Controller suspended the travel of aircraft, vehicles, and sea-going vessels into and out of West New Britain Province in response to a rise in COVID-19 cases.  3) The National Pandemic Controller has also delegated authority to provincial governments to establish their own requirements for travel, including on whether negative PCR COVID tests are required. Travelers who intend to travel from the National Capital District to other provinces are strongly encouraged to confirm any requirements with their respective airline(s) prior to travel."    Additionally, there are specific controls into the Autonomous Region of Bougainville (AROB), taken by the autonomous government there. Per the US Embassy's page,    "Additionally, travelers who enter Papua New Guinea via Port Moresby and then travel to AROB and who are not in possession of a medical health certificate attesting to their health and fitness to travel may be required to undergo an additional 14 days quarantine in AROB."    Per the Autonomous Bouganville Government's "Notice for travelers to Bougainville" dated 26th January, 2021,    "1. ALL intending travellers into Bougainville must present the following travel documents at the airports or sea ports:    1.1 A Covid-19 Medical Clearance Certificate issued by recognised public and private Medical Officer,    1.2 Health Declaration Forms as issued by Airline of Choice for routine quarantine checks in Buka or Aropa Port." etc.    See US Embassy in PNG's webpage, archived at https://archive.vn/B1hBc  See the Autonomous Bougainville Government's notice to travellers, archived at https://archive.vn/29TOt

Travelers approved for quarantine at an alternate site, such as a residence, may be required to use, and pay for the use of, a tracking device to ensure compliance with quarantine protocols.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As per the US Embassy in PNG's website, foreign travellers are allowed to come into PNG but only for very specific reasons, and are largely required to quarantine for 14 days at a government-approved facility.    "Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter? Yes. but please read this section carefully. Travelers are only allowed to enter with a valid visa and explicit written approval to enter from the National Pandemic Controller. Under measures instituted by the National Pandemic Controller, incoming travelers are only allowed to enter by air at Port Moresby International Airport. In general, travelers should not attempt to enter the country via its sea and land borders unless they have explicit approval to do so. Visas on arrival are not available at this time.  U.S. citizens who wish to enter the country must submit to covid19-travel@police.gov.pg the following as early as possible. Approvals granted after January 15, 2021 are valid for 90 days and may only be used for entry once. Travelers may also submit documentation via Air Niugini at nocapproval@airniugini.com.pg.  1) Cover letter stating the reason for travel and any compelling circumstances, as well information on the planned itinerary. See a sample letter here.  2) Completed Air Passenger Travel Form, including date of travel to Papua New Guinea, selected quarantine hotel/location, and a copy of the traveler’s passport  3) Copy of the traveler’s passport biodata page  4) Copy of the traveler’s Papua New Guinean work permit (if applicable)  5) Copy of the traveler’s Papua New Guinean visa (if applicable)  6) Proof of 14 days quarantine at one of the facilities named in Schedule 4 of Measure 2 regarding international travel."    "Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? Yes. All incoming travelers are required to quarantine at an government-approved quarantine site. A full list of approved quarantine sites may be found in Measure 2 – International Travel Measures, which is available at the government’s COVID-19 information portal. Most travelers must quarantine for 14 days. Additionally, travelers who enter Papua New Guinea via Port Moresby and then travel to AROB and who are not in possession of a medical health certificate attesting to their health and fitness to travel may be required to undergo an additional 14 days quarantine in AROB."    See US Embassy in PNG's webpage, archived at https://archive.vn/B1hBc

Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Papua New Guinea? Yes  If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  Symptomatic persons are generally able to obtain government-paid or government-subsidized testing services at Port Moresby General Hospital and the Taurama Aquatic Center drive-through testing site operated by St. John Ambulance service. Testing services outside of Port Moresby may be obtained by visiting a provincial hospital or by calling 1800 200 and asking for more information.  Non-symptomatic persons and persons who need testing services in connection with travel may obtain such services through approved swabbing centers and private medical facilities, including:  St John Ambulance  2K Medical Clinic  Pacific International Hospital  Aspen Medical  Sky Medical Services  Testing conducted through private medical facilities may cost as much as 250 USD.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://pg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As per the media statement on 17th February, The Controller of the PNG COVID-19 National Pandemic Response said PNG - specificially in the National Capital District - is ramping up testing using rapid antigen tests, but are re-confirming positive tests with GeneXpert (a form of RT-PCR test initially used for tuberculosis).    See the PNG National Department of Health's Facebook post/media release, archived at https://archive.vn/bfZLR    "He announced that there are four urban clinics in the NCD that are now doing swabbing for COVID-19 tests for those with symptoms of COVID-19 where members of the public can also get their test results within a short time for free. These are Badili, Tokarara, Morata and Gordons clinics. These sites are part of the nine clinics that have been selected to participate in the Antigen (Ag) Rapid Diagnosis (RDT) validation in NCD. The public will be informed when the rest of the nine clinics begin swabbing too.  Other sites that are also providing routine swabbing for symptomatic clients are Pari clinic in Moresby South, and the Port Moresby General Hospital. The general public are encouraged to utilize any of these services to check for COVID-19 infection.  Mr Manning said that this Antigen test is easy and results will be given within 20 to 30 minutes. Further GeneXpert testing is then performed on positive samples to confirm if the patient has the coronavirus disease or not. The turnaround time is about an hour which is more convenient for isolation and contact tracing.  He also confirmed that Rita Flynn is no longer swabbing but only tests the positive samples it receives from the urban sites to confirm, using GeneXpert. All negative samples from the Ag test are sent to CPHL for confirmation."

The code of 1G continues to be valid and signifies that the educational arrangements are significantly different to the situation prior to the Covid-19 pandemic.  The "safe management measures" from the Ministry of Education FAQ page are detailed below:    "With school reopening in 2021, what are the safe management measures put in place in schools?"    "Safe management measures in schools will continue to include the following:    Screening    Twice-daily temperature-taking and visual screening for all students and staff.  Students and staff who are unwell, or who have household members on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice or have adult household members with flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough, are required to stay away from school.  It is not mandatory for students to have their TraceTogether tokens when school reopens. The tokens will only be required in schools after nationwide distribution is completed.    Hygiene    Frequent cleaning of high-touch surfaces and disinfection of the premises to be done daily.  Students will continue to practise frequent hand-washing throughout the school day and wipe down of tables and shared equipment after use.    Safe Distancing    Fixed group seating of up to eight from the same class will be allowed.  CCAs and external learning journeys of up to 50 people conducted in a fixed group with exclusive use of venues (if possible) are allowed.  Curricular, co-curricular and enrichment activities with fixed intermingling across schools are allowed.  Staggered arrival, dismissal and recess timings to reduce congestion."    From SG Ministry of Education FAQs.  (Cannot be archived as the page consists of drop down items.  The page link is here:  https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection).

The "safe management measures" from the Ministry of Education FAQ page are detailed below:    "With school reopening in 2021, what are the safe management measures put in place in schools?"    "Safe management measures in schools will continue to include the following:    Screening    Twice-daily temperature-taking and visual screening for all students and staff.  Students and staff who are unwell, or who have household members on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice or have adult household members with flu-like symptoms such as fever and cough, are required to stay away from school.  It is not mandatory for students to have their TraceTogether tokens when school reopens. The tokens will only be required in schools after nationwide distribution is completed.    Hygiene    Frequent cleaning of high-touch surfaces and disinfection of the premises to be done daily.  Students will continue to practise frequent hand-washing throughout the school day and wipe down of tables and shared equipment after use.    Safe Distancing    Fixed group seating of up to eight from the same class will be allowed.  CCAs and external learning journeys of up to 50 people conducted in a fixed group with exclusive use of venues (if possible) are allowed.  Curricular, co-curricular and enrichment activities with fixed intermingling across schools are allowed.  Staggered arrival, dismissal and recess timings to reduce congestion."        Will all CCAs and school activities be resumed? [UPDATED, 18 Feb, 6:45pm]  Most CCAs and school activities are allowed to resume while activities that involve the following will remain suspended:    Trips to view external performances due to higher risk of intermingling with other schools and the public;  Activities with high level of body contact such as Taekwondo sparring, Rugby scrum and tackle;  Overnight camps.  Schools will continue to safeguard our students' well-being during CCAs and school activities, by implementing the necessary safe management measures (SMMs). This includes minimising prolonged inter-mingling between students and members of the public for activities held at external venues, such as Learning Journeys.    From SG Ministry of Education FAQs.  (Cannot be archived as the page consists of drop down items.  The page link is here:  https://www.moe.gov.sg/faqs-covid-19-infection).

***recoded from 2G to 1G; while C4 is coded at 4G to reflect private gathering limits in homes, large events - including worship services, indoor and outdoor musical ceremonies - are still allowed, making 1G a better fit since all public events are clearly not banned.     Previous coding note:     The coding notes advise using a code of "2" in situations where private gatherings are limited to below 10 people (which is the situation in Singapore).  However, in previous official advice on public gatherings, a strategy of piloting some events is discussed with up to 5 zones of 50 people (see below).  In addition, as the previous notes on 26th January and 28th December comment, some public events appear to be allowed including religious services and live indoor performances although there are restrictions with segregation between groups of people at the venue, social distancing and limits on the size of the events.    The code for C3 appears to be intermediate between 1G and 2G - some events can go ahead (within safe management guidelines), some cannot (particularly the larger ones).  For the moment, the code has been left as "2" with the flag "G" to reflect the general geographic scope.    Link:  http://archive.today/2021.02.12-190710/https://www.stb.gov.sg/content/stb/en/home-pages/advisory-for-MICE.html

The move to Phase 3 policy restrictions at the end of 2020 in Singapore appears to be accompanied by progressive relaxing of restrictions relating to public events.  Prior to this examples of public events which were allowed included Cinema and indoor live performances.  Straits Times notes "Live performances for the arts resumed cautiously with small scale trials for audience groups of 50 in September. Audience capacity was expanded to 100, in two groups of 50, on Nov 1." These were allowed with strict safe management measures such as social distancing and limits on the size of events.    In December, Straits Times reported that the easing of restrictions in Phase 3 included allowing indoor live performances and the piloting of outdoor live performances for up to 250 people.  Distancing rules included the separation of the audience into groups of 50 with a 3m gap between groups and a 1m gap between individuals within the groups. Similar rules have also applied to MICE events which have a business rather than recreational/leisure function.    The article in Straits Times also refers to an "indoor concert at the Sands Theatre at Marina Bay Sands on Dec 18 and 19, with mandatory pre-event testing, that had 400 in the audience".  Also, "The Singapore Symphony Orchestra conducted a similar pilot, with mandatory testing for an audience of 400 at the Esplanade Concert Hall for its Christmas fundraising concert on Dec 16."      http://archive.today/2021.02.13-160106/https://www.straitstimes.com/life/arts/phase-3-re-opening-outdoor-performance-pilots-for-audiences-of-250-indoor-audience-limit

MOH advisory on Phase 3 measures.  Initially released in December, the link remains current on the MOH website with updated information    "we will allow all ROs [Religious Organisations] to increase their capacity for congregational and other worship services to up to 250 persons (in zones of up to 50 persons each for congregational services). Congregational and other worship services as well as religious rites/ prayers conducted at places of worship may involve live performance elements (e.g. with a limited number of singers, wind and other instruments) with the necessary safe management measures in place."    "Going forward, we will allow indoor live performances to have up to 250 persons in zones of up to 50 persons each. We will also be expanding outdoor live performance pilots to 250 persons in zones of up to 50 persons each, to ensure that venues are still able to safely manage larger outdoor performances and mitigate the gathering of peripheral crowds."    "We will continue to conduct pilots in some higher-risk activities and settings such as busking and live performances in outdoor venues, karaoke, nightlife, which will allow us to assess how these activities can take place and scale up safely. "    http://archive.today/2021.02.26-143706/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moving-into-phase-three-of-re-opening

Straits Times Article: refers to easing of travel restrictions in relation to Australia NSW and a tightening of restrictions in relation to Vietnam including a ban for short term visitors from Feb 13th.    "Visitors from Vietnam will face tighter restrictions when entering Singapore from Saturday (Feb 13) due to an increase in Covid-19 cases in the country, in the latest border measures announced on Tuesday by the Ministry of Health (MOH) to safeguard public health and curb potential transmission to the community.    Short-term travellers holding an air travel pass (ATP) who had visited Vietnam within the last 14 days will not be allowed into Singapore, said MOH."    http://archive.today/2021.02.12-153446/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/tighter-border-measures-for-travellers-from-vietnam-and-business-travel-pass-holders

The SG government approach to border controls is summarised in the link below.      In broad terms,  the guidelines separate arrivals into specific groups: citizens, permanent residents, families of citizens and permanent residents, long term pass holders, short term visitors and work pass holders.      Short term visitors are allowed to enter Singapore for "any purpose of travel" under the Air Travel Pass Scheme if they are travelling from Australia, Brunei Darussalam,  Mainland China, New Zealand and Taiwan.  As noted on 9th February, this arrangement has been suspended for Vietnam.    Short term visitors are also permitted to enter Singapore under the Green Lanes Scheme if the purpose of the visit is "Business and Official Travel" AND if they are travelling from Brunei Darussalam, Germany, Indonesia, Japan, Mainland China, Malaysia and the Republic of Korea.    By implication, this means that short term visitors are not allowed into Singapore for "Any Purpose of Travel" if their departure point is not listed.  Thus the code for C8 continues to be a "3" - ban arrivals from some regions.    http://archive.today/2021.02.13-150455/https://safetravel.ica.gov.sg/arriving/overview

Vaccine: Pfizer-BioNTech.  Groups: "A,C:"    Article from Straits Times refers to the roll out of the vaccine to airline staff and maritime workers since January.  These workers who are referred to as "front line workers" in the article and could be considered to be "Key workers" in terms of the coding scheme.  However, it may also be relevant to consider these workers in terms described by the Minister of Health as those "who are in jobs or settings where risk of a super-spreading event is high" (see M1, 2nd February for link)    "Front-line workers in the aviation and maritime sectors started getting jabs on Jan 13 as part of an operational trial, before the mass exercise began in earnest on Jan 18.  Bus and train workers started getting jabs from Jan 25."    "Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung, who spoke to crew members operating SQ956 on Thursday morning, said the vaccination drive has been "proceeding like clockwork".  He told reporters he is confident that a substantial number of workers from the aviation and maritime sectors will be fully vaccinated by the end of the month."    http://archive.today/2021.02.12-202659/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/first-flights-with-fully-vaccinated-crew-depart-singapore-in-milestone-for-sia

"The first shipment of Moderna COVID-19 vaccine arrived in Singapore today (17 Feb) on Flight SQ 7137 at 1340H"    http://archive.today/2021.02.22-150440/https://www.sgpc.gov.sg/media_releases/mcimd/press_release/P-20210217-1

Groups: A,C    Singapore Ministry of Health Announcement 19TH FEB 2021           We are making good progress in our vaccination efforts. As of 18 February 2021, about 250,000 individuals have received their first dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Amongst them, more than 110,000 have also received their second dose of the vaccine, and completed the full vaccination regimen. Following the successful pilots in Ang Mo Kio and Tanjong Pagar, we will commence COVID-19 vaccinations for seniors in the community from 22 February.    3.    COVID-19 vaccination for seniors will commence island-wide from 22 February. Over the next three weeks, seniors aged 70 years and above can expect to receive personalised letters inviting them to sign up for vaccination. We will start by inviting seniors living near polyclinics or vaccination centres, so that they can be conveniently vaccinated at a vaccination site near their home. By mid-March when we have opened a vaccination centre in each town, all seniors will be able to receive their vaccination. We expect all the letters to reach our seniors aged 70 years and above by the first week of March.    4.    Thereafter we will move to vaccinate the seniors aged 60 to 69 years. They will receive their invitation letters around the middle of March, and the vaccination will commence from around end-March onwards.    8.   To ensure that seniors can conveniently receive their vaccinations, we will set up more vaccination centres in the coming weeks. Currently, there are 11 vaccination centres in operation[3]. Three more vaccination centres located at community centres/clubs will commence operations by 22 February, at Bukit Timah, Marine Parade and Taman Jurong, bringing the total to 14. By the middle of March, 31 vaccination centres will be in operation, with at least one vaccination centre in each town. In total, there will eventually be around 40 vaccination centres, with each vaccination centre planned for an estimated capacity of 2,000 vaccinations per day.    http://archive.today/2021.02.22-144640/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/start-of-covid-19-vaccination-for-seniors    Coding note: the code for H7 was previously changed from 1G to 2G on 27th January in response to the pilot vaccination programme for elderly groups at Ang Mo Kio and Tanjong Pagar.

"    http://archive.today/2021.02.26-142510/https://www.lta.gov.sg/content/ltagov/en/newsroom/2021/2/news-releases/COVID-19_vaccinations_for_active_taxi_and_private_hire_car_drivers.html

Yes  However, all individuals who have any of the following symptoms – fever greater than 37.5 degrees Celsius, cough, and/or breathing difficulties – are prohibited from boarding buses, ships, or aircrafts and must complete the Mandatory Medical Declaration form. They will be taken to a health facility for COVID-19 testing; positive cases will be subject to therapeutic isolation.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210222182612/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

At the time of this update, Timorese citizens and foreign nationals who are referred by a doctor for COVID-19 testing can obtain testing at the National Hospital, free of charge. Those seeking to test or experiencing COVID-19-like symptoms should call 119. COVID-19 testing is also available for a fee through the National Hospital for those needing COVID-free certification for international travel. Test results in English can be obtained directly from the National Health Laboratory or can be sent via email. Timor-Leste’s COVID-19 testing conditions are current as of the time of this update. Fees and services are subject to change; therefore, please confirm pricing when scheduling an appointment. Contact tracing is ongoing.    Six of the seven new cases are all from aldeia Klauhalek, suku Belulik Leten from Covalima municipality. These cases were detected through mass sample screening on 20 February 2021. Following  these cases, the epidemiology surveillance team carried out contact tracing as per the national surveillance and contact tracing guideline for COVID-19. The government has placed a sanitary health fence to contain any further transmission at the local level. Through the Integrated Center for Crises Management, the government and the MoH request everyone not to panic and indulge in spreading unverified information and rumours. The authorities also ask everyone to follow the COVID-19 preventive measures for everyone’s safety. The surveillance team, as per the national guideline is working on further investigation and contact tracing. Tests for CoViD-19 can now be processed in Tonga in a new laboratory extension which was officially opened today by Prime Minister Hon Dr Pohiva Tu’i’onetoa at Vaiola Hospital in Tongatapu in June 2020.  Two CoViD-19 testing machines, GeneXpert donated by the World Health Organization, and one PCR machine purchased by the Ministry of Health, are set up in the lab ready for processing swab samples.  The third machine, also a PCR, is kept as a backup.     Given the small number of machines for testing, the testing policies would be eligible only. Article from Matangitonga online news:    Announcement on vaccine distribution from COVAX facility.  Refers to the distribution of vaccines in the first half of 2021 which will be followed by a further distribution later in the year.    Tonga nominally allotted 43,800 doses from AZ/SKBio manufacturing source.  However no precise date is given for when vaccines will arrive and article notes the number of doses may change.  (Context note: population of Tonga is in region of 100,000 people)    "The other 10 Pacific countries with indicative doses of AZ/SKBio are:    Fiji 100,800 doses;  Kiribati – 48,000;  Marshall Islands – 24,000;  Micronesia (Federated States of) – 48,000;  Nauru – 7,200;  New Zealand 249,600;  Samoa – 79,200;  Tonga – 43,200  Tuvalu – 4,800  Vanuatu 100,800.    The indicative distribution is intended to provide interim guidance to COVAX Facility participating countries to help their governments and public health leaders to plan and prepare for the first rounds of vaccine distribution this year, and a successful national roll out of vaccines.    “It is therefore non-binding and may be subject to change,” the forecast stated."    http://archive.today/2021.02.08-141121/https://matangitonga.to/2021/02/06/covax-facility-announces-vaccines-release-first-half-2021

No update from what is published last with regards to availability of vaccine.  The COVAX Initiative expects to release first doses of the Pfizer/BioNTec vaccine and the AstraZeneca/Oxford vaccine during the first half of 2021 to COVAX Facility participants. Twelve South Pacific countries are included in its first “interim distribution forecast” that targets at least 3% of their populations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210212222315/https://matangitonga.to/2021/02/06/covax-facility-announces-vaccines-release-first-half-2021

"The People's Committee of HCM City has directed all educational establishments in the city to remain closed and resume online study until Feb 28. Under the city's original plan, students would have returned to schools and universities on Feb 17. But, under the new directive, they will resume online study after the Tet holiday until February 28 to maintain the academic year schedule."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215184054/https://www.thestar.com.my/aseanplus/aseanplus-news/2021/02/15/vietnam-schools-universities-in-ho-chih-minh-city-to-continue-online-study-until-feb-28-33-local-covid-19-cases-confirmed

"Schools in Ho Chi Minh City resumed on March 1 following a month-long break to prevent the spread of the pandemic."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301055144/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/vietnam-business-operations-and-the-coronavirus-updates.html/      "Students from kindergarten to high school levels would return to school on March 2, while those from vocational schools would return on March 8. University student schedules would be determined by the schools themselves, though the National Steering Committee for Covid-19 Prevention and Control recommended they reopen starting March 15 to ensure social distancing measures, the municipal People’s Committee said Saturday."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301053353/https://vietreader.com/life/34925-students-in-hanoi-will-be-back-to-school-next-week-as-covid-under-control.html

"Ho Chi Minh City authorities announced the closure of all non-essential businesses and entertainment activities such as bars, beauty salons, gyms, karaoke parlors, night clubs, massage parlors, and movie theaters from February 9 until further notice in response to the city recording more than 25 cases in a single day.  ...  Authorities in Vinh Phuc province have ordered the closure of karaoke parlors, bars, nightclubs, and online gaming centers from February 2 until further notice in a bid to prevent the further spread of the pandemic.  February 1  ...  Hanoi authorities have ordered the closure of bars, karaoke parlors, and nightclubs from February 1, until further notice, while several northern provinces such as Bac Ninh, Son La and Cao Bang have canceled entertainment activities such as spring festivities."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215191107/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/vietnam-business-operations-and-the-coronavirus-updates.html/

"Ho Chi Minh City authorities will reopen most non-essential businesses from March 1, such as restaurants, movie theaters, wedding centers, and tourist monuments/museums, however, bars, night clubs, karaoke parlors, gyms, and pool table services will remain closed for now."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301055144/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/vietnam-business-operations-and-the-coronavirus-updates.html/

"A number of festivals and events in Vietnam have been cancelled or postponed in alignment with the government’s directive to avoid public gatherings:  - Hu? Festival 2020 - Postponed to 2021  - F1 Vietnam Grand Prix - Cancelled  - Techcombank Ha Noi Marathon - March 26-28, 2021  - Vietnam Trail Marathon 2021 - Cancelled"    http://web.archive.org/web/20210210070843/https://vietnam.travel/things-to-do/information-travellers-novel-coronavirus-vietnam

"[T]he gathering of more than 20 people remains banned while non-essential businesses such as beauty salons, karaoke, movie theaters, and gyms remain closed.  ...  Ho Chi Minh City authorities announced... religious gatherings will be limited to 20 people. However, gas stations, retail stores, pharmacies and medical facilities will remain open but with strict preventive measures."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215191107/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/vietnam-business-operations-and-the-coronavirus-updates.html/

Feb 9: "Interprovincial transportation with H?i Duong Province is suspended for a period of 21 days.  Qu?ng Ninh Province has suspended interprovincial transportation and tourism operations, including cruises, hotels and restaurants until further notice. All flights and operations at Van Don International Airport are temporarily suspended."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210210070843/https://vietnam.travel/things-to-do/information-travellers-novel-coronavirus-vietnam      Jan 28: "The authorities have reported a further 100 cases on January 28 linked to the two community cases in Hai Duong and Quang Ninh... As a response, Quang Ninh and Hai Duong have suspended all public and passenger transport."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215191107/https://www.vietnam-briefing.com/news/vietnam-business-operations-and-the-coronavirus-updates.html/

It has been over 21 days, so the suspension of public and passenger transport schools in Quang Ninh and Hai Duong is no longer in affect.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210201165815/https://vietnamnet.vn/en/society/pm-orders-residents-in-hai-duong-quang-ninh-not-to-leave-localities-709115.html

"Earlier on February 4, Hanoi’s government issued Directive 03/CT-UBND suspending festivals, religious ceremonies, sports tournaments, and large events; the Directive also advises residents only to leave their houses when necessary, practice social distancing, and wear face masks in public places... Other cities and provinces in Vietnam may implement similar measures with little notice."    https://vn.usembassy.gov/reports-of-extended-quarantine-beyond-fourteen-days/

Feb 9: "Interprovincial transportation with H?i Duong Province is suspended for a period of 21 days.  Qu?ng Ninh Province has suspended interprovincial transportation and tourism operations, including cruises, hotels and restaurants until further notice. All flights and operations at Van Don International Airport are temporarily suspended."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210210070843/https://vietnam.travel/things-to-do/information-travellers-novel-coronavirus-vietnam

"On January 5, the Vietnamese government issued Directive 01/CT-TTg calling for stricter border control, quarantine surveillance, and more drastic COVID-19 prevention measures.   As of today, the Vietnamese government continues to suspend entry into Vietnam to all foreigners, including people with a Vietnamese visa exemption certificate.  This policy has very limited exemptions for diplomatic, official duty, and special cases, including experts, business managers, foreign investors, and high-tech workers of businesses involved in important projects as determined by the Government of Vietnam.  Family reunification is not one of the exemptions."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215192919/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.17836345.1442524452.1613413690-1517691061.1606106382

"The government introduced a fiscal support package valued VND 291.7 trillion (3.6 percent of GDP) to support the economy.   ...  Based on Resolution 42/CP, the government also approved a cash transfer package worth VND 36 trillion (0.5 percent of GDP) for affected workers and households with monthly cash transfers provided for no more than 3 months, from April to June. More than 10 percent of the population is estimated to benefit from this program. The Ministry of Finance estimated that approximately VND 12.7 trillion (35 percent of total package value) has been disbursed as of October 31 to the beneficiaries under this Resolution. Coverage of cash transfer program has been expanded to cover also the teachers of private schools."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210215192421/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Sep 30, 2020: "Tax relief measures include extended due dates for taxpayers to pay value added tax (VAT), individual (personal) income tax, and the amounts owed for land rental if the taxpayers are considered “vulnerable” in light of the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic. In particular:  30% CIT reduction: Businesses with total revenue in 2020 not exceeding VND200 billion (around USD8.5m) shall be entitled to a 30% reduction of CIT payable in 2020. Decree 114/2020/ND-CP dated 25 September 2020."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806224751/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/vietnam-tax-developments-in-response-to-covid-19.html

"There are currently 96 designated laboratories capable of conducting COVID-19 tests in Vietnam when mandated by the Vietnamese government."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215192919/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.17836345.1442524452.1613413690-1517691061.1606106382

"Due to the current COVID-19 situation in Hai Duong, Quang Ninh, Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Gia Lai, and Binh Duong, several regions in these provinces have been placed under lockdown.  Ho Chi Minh City, Hai Phong, Hoa Binh, Bac Giang, Dien Bien, Ha Giang, and Bac Ninh are taking pre-emptive actions, particularly contact-tracing and small-scale isolations, to minimize the possibility of an outbreak."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215192919/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.17836345.1442524452.1613413690-1517691061.1606106382

"n February 4, Hanoi’s government issued Directive 03/CT-UBND suspending festivals, religious ceremonies, sports tournaments, and large events.  The Directive also advises residents only to leave their houses when necessary, practice social distancing, and wear face masks in public places...  All people in Vietnam are advised to wear face masks and avoid close contact with others on public transportation."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215192919/https://vn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/?_ga=2.17836345.1442524452.1613413690-1517691061.1606106382

"Vietnam would receive around five million Covid-19 vaccine doses by the end of February, Deputy Health Minister Truong Quoc Cuong said at a meeting Tuesday.  They include about 4.9 million vaccine doses provided via Covax. About 117,000 other doses would be imported... by the end of February.    With the vaccine doses, five million people will receive the first shots, and three months later the second shots would be administered. Around two to five million people on the frontline of the coronavirus fight would be prioritized to get the vaccine."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215195049/https://vietreader.com/news/33728-vietnam-to-receive-five-million-covid-19-vaccine-doses-within-this-month.html

"Vietnam's government said on Tuesday health workers, diplomats and military personnel would be among the first to be vaccinated against COVID-19 when the country starts its inoculation programme next month.  ...  In the first quarter of 2021, Vietnam aims to inoculate 500,000 medical staff and 116,000 others directly involved in the fight against the pandemic, the government said in a statement.  ...  In the second quarter, Vietnam plans to vaccinate 1.8 million more people, including 9,200 customs officials, 4,080 diplomats, 1.03 million military personnel, 304,000 police officers and 550,000 teachers, the government said."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301063117/https://www.msn.com/en-au/lifestyle/wellbeing/vietnam-details-priorities-for-first-phase-of-covid-19-vaccinations/ar-BB1dVeLA?oci_d=mailsignout

entry to Vanuatu borders as of the 1 st of August 2020. Individual who wish to enter Vanuatu borders must meet the following conditions;     Vanuatu Citizens.  Permanent Resident ( Physically reside in Vanuatu for the last 3 years )  Foreigners with valid Residency permit issued before April 2020.  Business owners with a valid residency visa.  Dependents of the valid residency visa holders who are currently in Vanuatu. (Dependents will have to apply for a residency visa before arriving to Vanuatu).  Foreigners with a valid Special Category Visa issued before April 2020 will have to lodge an application to Immigration for consideration before approval will be granted to enter.  Partners must have a valid residency or Special Category Visa:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210215150445/https://immigration.gov.vu/index.php/news-updates/travel-notice

Employment Stabilization Payment in place from April, but applications closed September 15 2020.     See IMF Covid-19 Policy Responses (https://web.archive.org/web/20210215151708/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#V).

Hardship loans were provided in 2020, but the loan facility closed in May 2020. Commodity Support Grants, Shipping Support Grants and other support available for businesses from April, but applications closed November 30 2020.     See IMF Covid-19 Policy Responses (https://web.archive.org/web/20210215151708/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#V).

COVID-19 updates available on Ministry of Health's website, as well as posters, videos and detailed guidelines.   See COVID-19 Updates from the Vanuatu Ministry of Health (https://web.archive.org/web/20210215145404/https://covid19.gov.vu/).

Only those who meet the case definition for clinical symptoms, have travel history or contact with a COVID-19 case will be able to be tested.  See information on surveillance and testing from the Ministry of Health (https://web.archive.org/web/20210215152637/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/know-do/surveillance-and-testing).

A surveillance team in place to identify close contacts of those suspected or confirmed to have COVID-19, asked to quarantine for 14 days.   See information on surveillance and testing from the Ministry of Health (https://web.archive.org/web/20210215152637/https://covid19.gov.vu/index.php/know-do/surveillance-and-testing).
No cases are present meaning they are in scenario 1, no facemasks required:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226033529/https://covid19.gov.vu/

Vanuatu will soon work out a COVID-19 vaccination plan after its share of the coronavirus vaccine was approved on the 19th Feb by the World Health Organization-led COVAX facility which helps poor countries get vaccines:  http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2021-02/23/c_139761364.htm
